title: Update regarding GENE
story_body:
Genetic Technologies Limited (ASX: GENE) announced today the appointment of Dr. Sarah Chen as Senior Bioinformatics Engineer, expanding its computational genomics infrastructure team. Dr. Chen brings 12 years of experience in next-generation sequencing (NGS) pipeline optimization and variant calling algorithm development from her previous role at Illumina's DRAGEN Bio-IT platform division.

The appointment aligns with GENE's Q4 2023 roadmap to enhance its polygenic risk score (PRS) calculation throughput by 40 percent. Dr. Chen will oversee the implementation of GPU-accelerated GATK4 workflows and the migration of existing BWA-MEM2 alignment protocols to more efficient graph-based reference architectures.

"Dr. Chen's expertise in optimizing FPGA-based acceleration for germline variant discovery will be instrumental in reducing our per-sample computational costs," stated Chief Technology Officer Michael Torres. "Her work on distributed computing frameworks for population-scale genomics directly addresses our scalability requirements for the EasyDNA platform."

The company also reported progress on its environmental sustainability metrics, achieving a 23 percent reduction in data center power usage effectiveness (PUE) through the deployment of liquid immersion cooling systems for its high-performance computing clusters. The new infrastructure maintains optimal operating temperatures for NVIDIA DGX A100 systems while processing whole genome sequencing data at 30x coverage depth.

GENE's bioinformatics team has standardized on Kubernetes-orchestrated containerization for its variant annotation pipelines, enabling dynamic resource allocation across multi-cloud environments. The implementation of CWL (Common Workflow Language) specifications ensures reproducibility across different computational backends while maintaining HIPAA and ISO 27001 compliance standards.

Additionally, the company completed integration of its LIMS (Laboratory Information Management System) with updated REDCap databases, streamlining phenotype-genotype correlation studies. The enhanced system supports HL7 FHIR data exchange protocols, facilitating interoperability with electronic health record systems.

Dr. Chen's immediate priorities include optimizing the company's structural variant detection algorithms for long-read sequencing platforms and implementing machine learning models for improved pathogenicity prediction in rare variant interpretation. She will also lead the development of automated quality control metrics for the company's clinical-grade sequencing services.

The technical infrastructure improvements are expected to support GENE's expanding portfolio of pharmacogenomic testing services while maintaining turnaround times under 10 business days for standard panels.
